headline: Verizon to cut about 15,000 jobs, source says
summary:
STORY: Verizon is planning to cut about 15,000 jobs at the company - its largest workforce reduction ever.

That's according to a person familiar with the matter who spoke to Reuters on Thursday.

The move is part of new CEO Dan Schulman‚Äôs effort to restructure the telecom giant in the face of rising competition.

The source who spoke to Reuters said the layoffs will affect about 15% of Verizon's workforce... and are set to take place as soon as next week.

A Verizon spokesperson declined to comment.

The wireless carrier faces mounting market pressure amid concerns over a shrinking pool of new customers as older rivals - like AT&T and T-Mobile - offer cheaper plans and cable operators jump into the fray.

In the third quarter, Verizon added just 44,000 monthly bill-paying wireless subscribers, lagging AT&T, while T-Mobile led with more than 1 million net subscriber additions.

headline: Verizon CEO Says Company 'Has Not Performed for Our Shareholders'
summary: Verizon CEO Dan Schulman says he is not afraid to make "hard decisions" and that the company cannot continue losing market share "going forward."

content.title: Verizon CEO Says Company 'Has Not Performed for Our Shareholders'
content.description: Verizon CEO Dan Schulman says he is not afraid to make "hard decisions" and that the company cannot continue losing market share "going forward."

headline: Heard on the Street Thursday Recap: Seeing Red
summary: Stock indexes skidded, weighed down by tech shares and concerns the Federal Reserve will pause its rate-cutting campaign. The Nasdaq composite extended its November slide, dropping 2.3%, while the Dow industrials and S&P 500 both fell 1.

content.title: Heard on the Street Thursday Recap: Seeing Red
content.summary: Stock indexes skidded, weighed down by tech shares and concerns the Federal Reserve will pause its rate-cutting campaign. The Nasdaq composite extended its November slide, dropping 2.3%, while the Dow industrials and S&P 500 both fell 1.

headline: üéß Rate-Cut Doubts, Tech Selloff Knocked Stock Indexes on Thursday
summary: Technology stocks led a selloff amid concerns the Federal Reserve might pause its interest rate-cutting campaign.   Disney shares dropped nearly 8%, weighing on the Dow industrials, after the entertainment giant posted disappointing revenue.

headline: The Week in Numbers: shutdown relief, Burberry revival
summary:
STORY: From shutdown relief to a luxury recovery. 

This is the Week in Numbers.

:: The Week in Numbers

:: 43

43 days, the longest U.S. government shutdown in history, came to an end as U.S. President Donald Trump signed a funding package.

"The federal government will now resume normal operations. And my administration and our partners in Congress will continue our work to lower the cost of living, restore public safety, grow our economy, and make America affordable again for all Americans again.‚Äù

There had been strong opposition from House Democrats though.

They were angry that a long standoff launched by their Senate colleagues failed to secure a deal to extend federal health insurance subsidies. 

:: 15,000

Verizon is reportedly planning to cut about 15,000 jobs at the company - its largest workforce reduction ever.

With a potential 15% of Verizon's workforce impacted.

That's according to a person familiar with the matter who spoke to Reuters.

The move is part of new CEO Dan Schulman‚Äôs effort to restructure the telecom giant in the face of rising competition.

::6.6%

Shares of Disney plunged as much as 6.6% after the company warned of a potentially lengthy battle with YouTube TV.

It's over distribution of its television channels.

Disney's networks disappeared from YouTube TV - the fourth-largest pay-TV provider in the U.S. - in October. 

::4.9%

4.9% was China's industrial output growth year-on-year.

Its factory output and retail sales grew at their weakest pace in over a year for October.

The country's National Bureau of Statistics data showed growth at  the weakest annual pace since August 2024.

:: $25.5 million

$25.5 million was Burberry's operating profit for the six months ending late September. 

Burberry returned to growth in the second quarter.

The British luxury brand reported a 2% rise in comparable store sales .

The number ended seven quarters of decline and signals its turnaround measures are paying off.

headline: How Recent Developments Are Shaping the Verizon Investment Story
summary: Verizon Communications has seen a recent update to its fair value estimate, which remains steady at $47.53 per share even as several input assumptions have shifted. Analysts have raised the discount rate from 7.11 percent to 8.03 percent and adjusted revenue growth projections modestly lower. These changes reflect both optimism about ongoing company strategies and caution regarding industry headwinds. Stay tuned to discover how you can keep track of evolving perspectives on Verizon's stock...

headline: U.S. worker anxiety expected to rise in the 'forever layoffs' era
summary: The fourth quarter is traditionally a calm time for the employees, but 2025 has been different in many ways. Employers used to refrain from cutting jobs during the holiday quarter, but October proved to be a bloodbath. Through October, employers announced 1.1 million job cuts, a 65% year-over-year ...
